# Monitoring from Space how Air Pollution affects Climate Change

</br>
Bushfires across southeast Australia in the 2019-2020 season emitted about 700 million metric tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) into the atmosphere, more than double the emissions provided by fire emission inventory datasets, according to satellite data analysis in a new paper published in Nature.
</br>
</br>
Although Australia is no stranger to bushfires, the 2019-2020 season was unprecedented. As of March 2020, the fires had burned an estimated 18.6 million hectares (186,000 sq km, or nearly 46 million acres) destroying more than 5,000 buildings and killing more than 400 people. It was estimated that more than 1 billion animals perished from the bushfires, with several endangered species facing the risk of total extinction.
</br>
</br>
In southeast Australia, the fires were both intense and extensive. As much as 74,000 sq km (some 18.3 million acres) of mostly eucalyptus forest, roughly 2.5 times the area of Belgium, was affected. Previous estimates from global inventory datasets of wildfire emissions based on satellite fire data and modelled quantities of standing biomass suggested that the fires released on average 275 million metric tons of CO2 between November 2019 and January 2020.

Monitoring from Space how Air Pollution affects Climate Change


Bushfires across southeast Australia in the 2019-2020 season emitted about 700 million metric tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) into the atmosphere, more than double the emissions provided by fire emission inventory datasets, according to satellite data analysis in a new paper published in Nature.

Although Australia is no stranger to bushfires, the 2019-2020 season was unprecedented. As of March 2020, the fires had burned an estimated 18.6 million hectares (186,000 sq km, or nearly 46 million acres) destroying more than 5,000 buildings and killing more than 400 people. It was estimated that more than 1 billion animals perished from the bushfires, with several endangered species facing the risk of total extinction.

In southeast Australia, the fires were both intense and extensive. As much as 74,000 sq km (some 18.3 million acres) of mostly eucalyptus forest, roughly 2.5 times the area of Belgium, was affected. Previous estimates from global inventory datasets of wildfire emissions based on satellite fire data and modelled quantities of standing biomass suggested that the fires released on average 275 million metric tons of CO2 between November 2019 and January 2020.

features.text:
## Bushfires released about 700 million metric tons of CO2 in just 3 months

</br>
However, the new analysis indicates that this figure was a gross underestimate. Measurements from the Tropomi instrument on board ESA’s Copernicus Sentinel-5P satellite provided a more accurate estimate of the emissions
</br>
</br>
While Tropomi doesn’t directly measure CO2, the instrument takes daily snapshots of carbon monoxide (CO) levels in the atmospheric column beneath the satellite. These data were used to calculate a detailed estimate of the CO emissions from the bushfires, which were then used as a proxy for calculating CO2emissions.
</br>
</br>
The conclusion is that the bushfires released about 700 million metric tons of CO2 in just 3 months. This is twice the amount of CO2that had previously been suggested by fire inventory estimates, and it surpasses Australia’s normal annual bushfire and fossil fuel emissions by 80%.
</br>
</br>
This image uses information from ESA’s Copernicus Sentinel-5P mission and shows the average carbon monoxide (CO) concentrations from Nov. 1,  2019 to Jan. 31, 2020. Carbon monoxide is commonly associated with traffic, but the concentrations here are due to the bushfires.
